title.children: Hundreds feared dead after Gaza hospital explosion as Joe Biden heads to Israel

items.synopsis: The US president directs his national security team to investigate a blast that killed hundreds in Gaza ahead of his visit to Israel.Â Follow live for the latest updates.

title.children: Biden pledges investigation into Gaza hospital blast as additional repatriation flight for Australians confirmed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra. "We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said. "The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life. "Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian. "Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount. "We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese says 'every innocent life matters'

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese commented on the Gaza hospital blast during a joint press conference with Fijian Prime Minister
Â
Sitiveni Rabuka, who is visiting Canberra.
"We have seen a devastating loss of innocent life since the attacks on Israel by the terrorist group Hamas," Mr Albanese said.
"The scenes from the explosion at a Gaza City hospital are deeply distressing and it is clear that there has been a devastating loss of life.
"Every innocent life matters, whether it is Israeli or Palestinian.

"Our thoughts are with those killed, those injured and their loved ones. The protection of civilian lives must come first, as the parliament said in its resolution that we carried on Monday, and respect for international humanitarian law is paramount.
"We condemn any indiscriminate attacks and targeting of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals and Australia joins with others in calling for international law to always be upheld."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened. "I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement. "The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden expresses outrage over Gaza hospital blast, says US will investigate

children.content: US President Joe Biden says he is "outraged" by the explosion at al-Ahli Arab Hospital and said he had directed his national security team to gather information about exactly what had happened.
"I am outraged and deeply saddened by the explosion at the Al Ahli Arab hospital in Gaza, and the terrible loss of life that resulted," Biden, who is on his way to Israel, said in a statement.
"The United States stands unequivocally for the protection of civilian life during conflict and we mourn the patients, medical staff and other innocents killed or wounded in this tragedy."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai. A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians. Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed. Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan. She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government planning another repatriation flight today

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government is planning an additional departure flight today for Australians trying to leave Tel Aviv for Dubai.
A government assisted-departure flight landed in Sydney from Dubai last night, carrying 222 passengers, including 164 Australians.
Meanwhile, 46 registered Australians remain in Gaza, with the Rafah border crossing with Egypt still closed.
Senator Wong says the government is also supporting departure options for Australians in the West Bank, including working with partners to arrange transport to Jordan.
She says more than 1,500 Australians have now left Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest figures from the ABS show the number of new home builds being started has fallen to the lowest level since March 2013. The June quarter Building Activity data show 40,720 new dwelling units were commenced during that three-month period, driven by a 4.4% fall in private sector detached house commencements since the previous quarter. Private new house commencements were down more than 15% over the past year, while multi-dwelling building starts, mainly apartments, have broadly flatlined. At 41,669, the number of new homes being completed in the June quarter was the lowest in more than nine years, since March 2014. However, the number of dwellings still under construction remains near historical highs, highlighting the effect of building delays over recent years, due to skills shortages, materials shortages and/or bad weather. Housing construction has also been massively skewed by the effect of the Morrison government's HomeBuilder scheme, which saw many people bring forward their decision to build a new house in order to attract a subsidy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New home building hits decade low

children.content: The latest figures from the ABS show the number of new home builds being started has fallen to the lowest level since March 2013.

The June quarter Building Activity data show 40,720 new dwelling units were commenced during that three-month period, driven by a 4.4% fall in private sector detached house commencements since the previous quarter.
Private new house commencements were down more than 15% over the past year, while multi-dwelling building starts, mainly apartments, have broadly flatlined.
At 41,669, the number of new homes being completed in the June quarter was the lowest in more than nine years, since March 2014.

However, the number of dwellings still under construction remains near historical highs, highlighting the effect of building delays over recent years, due to skills shortages, materials shortages and/or bad weather.

Housing construction has also been massively skewed by the effect of the Morrison government's HomeBuilder scheme, which saw many people bring forward their decision to build a new house in order to attract a subsidy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Queensland Government has announced $50 million in funding to support mine workers and the Mount Isa community, after Glencore announced it would close its copper mines by 2025. Up to $30 million will be spent on accelerating mining projects in the area over the next 5 years. Up to $20 million, which will be matched dollar-for-dollar by Glencore, will be spent on an 'economic structural adjustment' package for Mount Isa. The Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says North West Queensland will remain at the heart of the state's mining future. "Our number one priority is to protect jobs and retain skilled workers in this important region. I understand many workers and their families will find Glencore's decision a difficult one to accept. But we will always do what we can to support workers and their families to find new good, secure jobs," she said. The matched funding will be in addition to any support Glencore is obliged to provide to the affected workforce.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Funding to help Mount Isa community and mine workers

children.content: The Queensland Government has announced
$50 million in funding to support mine workers and the Mount Isa community,
after Glencore announced it would close its copper mines by 2025.
Up to $30 million will be spent on accelerating mining projects in the area
over the next 5 years.
Up to $20 million, which will be matched dollar-for-dollar by Glencore, will be spent on an 'economic structural adjustment'
package for Mount Isa.
The Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says North West Queensland will remain at the heart of the state's mining future.
"Our number one priority is to protect jobs and retain skilled workers in this important region.
I understand many workers and their families will find Glencore's decision a difficult one to accept.
But we will always do what we can to support workers and their families to find new good, secure jobs," she said.
The matched funding will be in addition to any support Glencore is obliged to provide to the affected workforce.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Unions are calling on the Queensland government and Glencore to provide support to workers, after the company announced it would close its copper mines by 2025. At least 1,200 employees will be affected. Australian Workers' Union Queensland secretary Stacey Schinnerl says it's a sad day for the entire Mount Isa community. "Now is the time for the government to cut through the green tape and fast-track approvals for new mines in the region to provide a suitable transition for affected workers. We are calling on Glencore to provide redeployment opportunities to local workers who will be affected by these closures," she said. In a statement, Glencore's chief operating officer, Sam Strohmayr says studies revealed the remaining mineral resources were not economically viable due to low ore grades, a lack of safe extraction areas and ageing infrastructure. "The reality of mining is that mines have a beginning, middle and end. And unfortunately after 60 years of operation, Mount Isa's underground copper operations have now reached that end." He says the focus over the next few months will be providing support to employees, contractors, suppliers and the Mount Isa community. "It's too early to put a figure on how many people may receive redundancies until we work through a process of speaking to each worker and discuss options around retention, redeployment, and retaining. Redundancies are the last resort and will be offered only when other options have been exhausted." The company says its other metal assets, including the copper smelter, George Fisher mine, zinc-lead concentrator and lead smelter, will all continue operating in Mount Isa.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Unions call for support after news of mine closures in Mount Isa

children.content: Unions are
calling on the Queensland government and Glencore to provide support to workers
, after the company announced it would close its copper mines by 2025.
At least 1,200 employees will be affected.
Australian Workers' Union Queensland secretary Stacey Schinnerl says it's a sad day for the entire Mount Isa community.
"Now is the time for the government to cut through the green tape and fast-track approvals for new mines in the region to provide a suitable transition for affected workers.
We are calling on Glencore to provide redeployment opportunities to local workers who will be affected by these closures," she said.
In a statement, Glencore's chief operating officer, Sam Strohmayr says studies revealed the remaining mineral resources
were not economically viable due to low ore grades, a lack of safe extraction areas and ageing infrastructure.
"The reality of mining is that mines have a beginning, middle and end. And unfortunately after 60 years of operation, Mount Isa's underground copper operations have now reached that end."
He says the
focus over the next few months will be providing support to employees, contractors, suppliers and the Mount Isa community.

"It's too early to put a figure on how many people may receive redundancies until we work through a process of speaking to each worker and discuss options around retention, redeployment, and retaining. Redundancies are the last resort and will be offered only when other options have been exhausted."
The company says its other metal assets, including the copper smelter, George Fisher mine, zinc-lead concentrator and lead smelter, will all continue operating in Mount Isa.

Ivan Soldo should make a difference in that Port engine room next year and beyond.
